segment.source: This topic explains the dependency property system that is available when you write a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic along with XAML definitions for UI.
segment.target: This topic explains the dependency property system that is available when you write a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic along with XAML definitions for UI.

segment.source: Dependency properties overview
segment.target: Dependency properties overview

segment.source: Dependency properties overview
segment.target: Dependency properties overview

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This topic explains the dependency property system that is available when you write a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic along with XAML definitions for UI.
segment.target: This topic explains the dependency property system that is available when you write a Windows Runtime app using C++, C#, or Visual Basic along with XAML definitions for UI.

segment.source: What is a dependency property?
segment.target: What is a dependency property?

segment.source: A dependency property is a specialized type of property.
segment.target: A dependency property is a specialized type of property.

segment.source: Specifically it's a property where the property's value is tracked and influenced by a dedicated property system that is part of the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Specifically it's a property where the property's value is tracked and influenced by a dedicated property system that is part of the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: In order to support a dependency property, the object that defines the property must be a DependencyObject (in other words a class that has the DependencyObject base class somewhere in its inheritance).
segment.target: In order to support a dependency property, the object that defines the property must be a DependencyObject (in other words a class that has the DependencyObject base class somewhere in its inheritance).

segment.source: Many of the types you use for your UI definitions for a Windows Store app with XAML will be a DependencyObject subclass, and will support dependency properties.
segment.target: Many of the types you use for your UI definitions for a Windows Store app with XAML will be a DependencyObject subclass, and will support dependency properties.

segment.source: However, any type that comes from a Windows Runtime namespace that doesn't have "XAML" in its name won't support dependency properties; properties of such types are ordinary properties that won't have the property system's dependency behavior.
segment.target: However, any type that comes from a Windows Runtime namespace that doesn't have "XAML" in its name won't support dependency properties; properties of such types are ordinary properties that won't have the property system's dependency behavior.

segment.source: The purpose of dependency properties is to provide a systemic way to compute the value of a property based on other inputs (other properties, events and states that occur within your app while it runs).
segment.target: The purpose of dependency properties is to provide a systemic way to compute the value of a property based on other inputs (other properties, events and states that occur within your app while it runs).

segment.source: These other inputs might include:
segment.target: These other inputs might include:

segment.source: External input such as user preference
segment.target: External input such as user preference

segment.source: Just-in-time property determination mechanisms such as data binding, animations and storyboards
segment.target: Just-in-time property determination mechanisms such as data binding, animations and storyboards

segment.source: Multiple-use templating patterns such as resources and styles
segment.target: Multiple-use templating patterns such as resources and styles

segment.source: Values known through parent-child relationships with other elements in the object tree
segment.target: Values known through parent-child relationships with other elements in the object tree

segment.source: A dependency property represents or supports a specific feature of the programming model for defining a Windows Runtime app with XAML for UI and C#, Microsoft Visual Basic or Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) for code.
segment.target: A dependency property represents or supports a specific feature of the programming model for defining a Windows Runtime app with XAML for UI and C#, Microsoft Visual Basic or Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX) for code.

segment.source: These features include:
segment.target: These features include:

segment.source: Data binding
segment.target: Data binding

segment.source: Styles
segment.target: Styles

segment.source: Storyboarded animations
segment.target: Storyboarded animations

segment.source: "PropertyChanged" behavior; a dependency property can be implemented to provide callbacks that can propagate changes to other dependency properties
segment.target: "PropertyChanged" behavior; a dependency property can be implemented to provide callbacks that can propagate changes to other dependency properties

segment.source: Using a default value that comes from property metadata
segment.target: Using a default value that comes from property metadata

segment.source: General property system utility such as ClearValue and metadata lookup
segment.target: General property system utility such as ClearValue and metadata lookup

segment.source: Dependency properties and Windows Runtime properties
segment.target: Dependency properties and Windows Runtime properties

segment.source: Dependency properties extend basic Windows Runtime property functionality by providing a global, internal property store that backs all of the dependency properties in an app at run time.
segment.target: Dependency properties extend basic Windows Runtime property functionality by providing a global, internal property store that backs all of the dependency properties in an app at run time.

segment.source: This is an alternative to the standard pattern of backing a property with a private field that's private in the property-definition class.
segment.target: This is an alternative to the standard pattern of backing a property with a private field that's private in the property-definition class.

segment.source: You can think of this internal property store as being a set of property identifiers and values that exist for any particular object (so long as it's a DependencyObject).
segment.target: You can think of this internal property store as being a set of property identifiers and values that exist for any particular object (so long as it's a DependencyObject).

segment.source: Rather than being identified by name, each property in the store is identified by a DependencyProperty instance.
segment.target: Rather than being identified by name, each property in the store is identified by a DependencyProperty instance.

segment.source: However, the property system mostly hides this implementation detail: you can usually access dependency properties by using a simple name (the programmatic property name in the code language you're using, or an attribute name when you're writing XAML).
segment.target: However, the property system mostly hides this implementation detail: you can usually access dependency properties by using a simple name (the programmatic property name in the code language you're using, or an attribute name when you're writing XAML).

segment.source: The base type that provides the underpinnings of the dependency property system is DependencyObject.
segment.target: The base type that provides the underpinnings of the dependency property system is DependencyObject.

segment.source: DependencyObject defines methods that can access the dependency property, and instances of a DependencyObject derived class internally support the property store concept we mentioned earlier.
segment.target: DependencyObject defines methods that can access the dependency property, and instances of a DependencyObject derived class internally support the property store concept we mentioned earlier.

segment.source: Here is a summation of the terminology that we use in the documentation when discussing dependency properties:
segment.target: Here is a summation of the terminology that we use in the documentation when discussing dependency properties:

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Dependency property
segment.target: Dependency property

segment.source: A property that exists on a DependencyProperty identifier (see below).
segment.target: A property that exists on a DependencyProperty identifier (see below).

segment.source: Usually this identifier is available as a static member of the defining DependencyObject derived class.
segment.target: Usually this identifier is available as a static member of the defining DependencyObject derived class.

segment.source: Dependency property identifier
segment.target: Dependency property identifier

segment.source: A SetValue, that's why it is typically public even though it is read-only.
segment.target: A SetValue, that's why it is typically public even though it is read-only.

segment.source: Property wrapper
segment.target: Property wrapper

segment.source: The callable get and set implementations for a Windows Runtime property.
segment.target: The callable get and set implementations for a Windows Runtime property.

segment.source: Or, the language-specific projection of the original definition.
segment.target: Or, the language-specific projection of the original definition.

segment.source: A get property wrapper implementation calls SetValue, passing the relevant dependency property identifier as one input and the value to set as the second input.
segment.target: A get property wrapper implementation calls SetValue, passing the relevant dependency property identifier as one input and the value to set as the second input.

segment.source: The property wrapper is not just convenience for callers, it also exposes the dependency property to any process, tool or projection that uses Windows Runtime definitions for properties.
segment.target: The property wrapper is not just convenience for callers, it also exposes the dependency property to any process, tool or projection that uses Windows Runtime definitions for properties.

segment.source: The following example defines a custom "IsSpinning" dependency property as defined for C#, and shows the relationship of the dependency property identifier to the property wrapper.
segment.target: The following example defines a custom "IsSpinning" dependency property as defined for C#, and shows the relationship of the dependency property identifier to the property wrapper.

segment.source: Note The preceding example is not intended as the complete example for how to create a custom dependency property.
segment.target: Note The preceding example is not intended as the complete example for how to create a custom dependency property.

segment.source: It is intended to show dependency property concepts for anyone that prefers learning concepts through code.
segment.target: It is intended to show dependency property concepts for anyone that prefers learning concepts through code.

segment.source: For a more complete example, see Custom dependency properties.
segment.target: For a more complete example, see Custom dependency properties.

segment.source: Dependency property value precedence
segment.target: Dependency property value precedence

segment.source: When you get the value of a dependency property, you are obtaining a value that was determined for that property through any one of the inputs that participate in the Windows Runtime property system.
segment.target: When you get the value of a dependency property, you are obtaining a value that was determined for that property through any one of the inputs that participate in the Windows Runtime property system.

segment.source: Dependency property value precedence exists so that the Windows Runtime property system can calculate values in a predictable way, and it's important that you be familiar with the basic precedence order too.
segment.target: Dependency property value precedence exists so that the Windows Runtime property system can calculate values in a predictable way, and it's important that you be familiar with the basic precedence order too.

segment.source: Otherwise, you might find yourself in a situation where you're trying to set a property at one level of precedence but something else (the system, third-party callers, some of your own code) is setting it at another level, and you'll get frustrated trying to figure out which property value is used and where that value came from.
segment.target: Otherwise, you might find yourself in a situation where you're trying to set a property at one level of precedence but something else (the system, third-party callers, some of your own code) is setting it at another level, and you'll get frustrated trying to figure out which property value is used and where that value came from.

segment.source: For example, styles and templates are intended to be a shared starting point for establishing property values and thus appearances of a control.
segment.target: For example, styles and templates are intended to be a shared starting point for establishing property values and thus appearances of a control.

segment.source: But on a particular control instance you might want to change its value versus the common templated value, such as giving that control a different background color or a different text string as content.
segment.target: But on a particular control instance you might want to change its value versus the common templated value, such as giving that control a different background color or a different text string as content.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime property system considers local values at higher precedence than values provided by styles and templates.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime property system considers local values at higher precedence than values provided by styles and templates.

segment.source: That enables the scenario of having app-specific values overwrite the templates so that the controls are useful for your own use of them in app UI.
segment.target: That enables the scenario of having app-specific values overwrite the templates so that the controls are useful for your own use of them in app UI.

segment.source: Dependency property precedence list
segment.target: Dependency property precedence list

segment.source: The following is the definitive order that the property system uses when assigning the run-time value for a dependency property.
segment.target: The following is the definitive order that the property system uses when assigning the run-time value for a dependency property.

segment.source: Highest precedence is listed first.
segment.target: Highest precedence is listed first.

segment.source: You'll find more detailed explanations just past this list.
segment.target: You'll find more detailed explanations just past this list.

segment.source: Animated values: Active animations, visual state animations, or animations with a HoldEnd behavior.
segment.target: Animated values: Active animations, visual state animations, or animations with a HoldEnd behavior.

segment.source: To have any practical effect, an animation applied to a property must have precedence over the base (unanimated) value, even if that value was set locally.
segment.target: To have any practical effect, an animation applied to a property must have precedence over the base (unanimated) value, even if that value was set locally.

segment.source: Local value: A local value might be set through the convenience of the property wrapper, which also equates to setting as an attribute or property element in XAML, or by a call to the SetValue method using a property of a specific instance.
segment.target: Local value: A local value might be set through the convenience of the property wrapper, which also equates to setting as an attribute or property element in XAML, or by a call to the SetValue method using a property of a specific instance.

segment.source: If you set a local value by using a binding or a static resource, these each act in the precedence as if a local value was set, and bindings or resource references are erased if a new local value is set.
segment.target: If you set a local value by using a binding or a static resource, these each act in the precedence as if a local value was set, and bindings or resource references are erased if a new local value is set.

segment.source: Templated properties: An element has these if it was created as part of a template (from a ControlTemplate or DataTemplate).
segment.target: Templated properties: An element has these if it was created as part of a template (from a ControlTemplate or DataTemplate).

segment.source: Style setters: Values from a Setter within styles from page or application resources.
segment.target: Style setters: Values from a Setter within styles from page or application resources.

segment.source: Default value: A dependency property can have a default value as part of its metadata.
segment.target: Default value: A dependency property can have a default value as part of its metadata.

segment.source: Templated properties
segment.target: Templated properties

segment.source: Templated properties as a precedence item do not apply to any property of an element that you declare directly in XAML page markup.
segment.target: Templated properties as a precedence item do not apply to any property of an element that you declare directly in XAML page markup.

segment.source: The templated property concept exists only for objects that are created when the Windows Runtime applies a XAML template to a UI element and thus defines its visuals.
segment.target: The templated property concept exists only for objects that are created when the Windows Runtime applies a XAML template to a UI element and thus defines its visuals.

segment.source: All the properties that are set from a control template have values of some kind.
segment.target: All the properties that are set from a control template have values of some kind.

segment.source: These values are almost like an extended set of default values for the control and are often associated with values you can reset later by setting the property values directly.
segment.target: These values are almost like an extended set of default values for the control and are often associated with values you can reset later by setting the property values directly.

segment.source: Thus the template-set values must be distinguishable from a true local value, so that any new local value can overwrite it.
segment.target: Thus the template-set values must be distinguishable from a true local value, so that any new local value can overwrite it.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: In some cases the template might override even local values, if the template failed to expose {TemplateBinding} markup extension references for properties that should have been settable on instances.
segment.target: In some cases the template might override even local values, if the template failed to expose {TemplateBinding} markup extension references for properties that should have been settable on instances.

segment.source: This is usually done only if the property is really not intended to be set on instances, for example if it's only relevant to visuals and template behavior and not to the intended function or runtime logic of the control that uses the template.
segment.target: This is usually done only if the property is really not intended to be set on instances, for example if it's only relevant to visuals and template behavior and not to the intended function or runtime logic of the control that uses the template.

segment.source: Bindings and precedence
segment.target: Bindings and precedence

segment.source: Binding operations have the appropriate precedence for whatever scope they're used for.
segment.target: Binding operations have the appropriate precedence for whatever scope they're used for.

segment.source: For example, a binding applied to a local value acts as local value, and a binding ({TemplateBinding} markup extension) for a property setter applies as a style setter does.
segment.target: For example, a binding applied to a local value acts as local value, and a binding ({TemplateBinding} markup extension) for a property setter applies as a style setter does.

segment.source: Because bindings must wait until run-time to obtain values from data sources, the process of determining the property value precedence for any property extends into run-time as well.
segment.target: Because bindings must wait until run-time to obtain values from data sources, the process of determining the property value precedence for any property extends into run-time as well.

segment.source: Not only do bindings operate at the same precedence as a local value, they really are a local value, where the binding is the placeholder for a value that is deferred.
segment.target: Not only do bindings operate at the same precedence as a local value, they really are a local value, where the binding is the placeholder for a value that is deferred.

segment.source: If you have a binding in place for a property value, and you set a local value on it at run-time, that replaces the binding entirely.
segment.target: If you have a binding in place for a property value, and you set a local value on it at run-time, that replaces the binding entirely.

segment.source: Similarly, if you call SetBinding to define a binding that only comes into existence at run-time, you replace any local value you might have applied in XAML or with previously executed code.
segment.target: Similarly, if you call SetBinding to define a binding that only comes into existence at run-time, you replace any local value you might have applied in XAML or with previously executed code.

segment.source: Storyboarded animations and base value
segment.target: Storyboarded animations and base value

segment.source: Storyboarded animations act on a concept of a base value.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations act on a concept of a base value.

segment.source: The base value is the value that's determined by the property system using its precedence, but omitting that last step of looking for animations.
segment.target: The base value is the value that's determined by the property system using its precedence, but omitting that last step of looking for animations.

segment.source: For example, a base value might come from a control's template, or it might come from setting a local value on an instance of a control.
segment.target: For example, a base value might come from a control's template, or it might come from setting a local value on an instance of a control.

segment.source: Either way, applying an animation will overwrite this base value and apply the animated value for as long as your animation continues to run.
segment.target: Either way, applying an animation will overwrite this base value and apply the animated value for as long as your animation continues to run.

segment.source: For an animated property, the base value can still have an effect on the animation's behavior, if that animation does not explicitly specify both From and To, or if the animation reverts the property to its base value when completed.
segment.target: For an animated property, the base value can still have an effect on the animation's behavior, if that animation does not explicitly specify both From and To, or if the animation reverts the property to its base value when completed.

segment.source: In these cases, once an animation is no longer running, the rest of the precedence is used again.
segment.target: In these cases, once an animation is no longer running, the rest of the precedence is used again.

segment.source: However, an animation that specifies a To with a HoldEnd behavior can override a local value until the animation is removed, even when it visually appears to be stopped.
segment.target: However, an animation that specifies a To with a HoldEnd behavior can override a local value until the animation is removed, even when it visually appears to be stopped.

segment.source: Conceptually this is like an animation that's running forever even if there is not a visual animation in the UI.
segment.target: Conceptually this is like an animation that's running forever even if there is not a visual animation in the UI.

segment.source: Multiple animations can be applied to a single property.
segment.target: Multiple animations can be applied to a single property.

segment.source: Each of these animations might have been defined to replace base values that came from different points in the value precedence.
segment.target: Each of these animations might have been defined to replace base values that came from different points in the value precedence.

segment.source: However, these animations will all be running simultaneously at run time, and that often means that they must combine their values because each animation has equal influence on the value.
segment.target: However, these animations will all be running simultaneously at run time, and that often means that they must combine their values because each animation has equal influence on the value.

segment.source: This depends on exactly how the animations are defined, and the type of the value that is being animated.
segment.target: This depends on exactly how the animations are defined, and the type of the value that is being animated.

segment.source: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info, see Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: Default values
segment.target: Default values

segment.source: Establishing the default value for a dependency property with a PropertyMetadata value is explained in more detail in the Custom dependency properties topic.
segment.target: Establishing the default value for a dependency property with a PropertyMetadata value is explained in more detail in the Custom dependency properties topic.

segment.source: Dependency properties still have default values even if those default values weren't explicitly defined in that property's metadata.
segment.target: Dependency properties still have default values even if those default values weren't explicitly defined in that property's metadata.

segment.source: Unless they have been changed by metadata, default values for the Windows Runtime dependency properties are generally one of the following:
segment.target: Unless they have been changed by metadata, default values for the Windows Runtime dependency properties are generally one of the following:

segment.source: A property that uses a run-time object or the basic Object type (a reference type) has a default value of null.
segment.target: A property that uses a run-time object or the basic Object type (a reference type) has a default value of null.

segment.source: For example, DataContext is null until it's deliberately set or is inherited.
segment.target: For example, DataContext is null until it's deliberately set or is inherited.

segment.source: A property that uses a basic value such as numbers or a Boolean value (a value type) uses an expected default for that value.
segment.target: A property that uses a basic value such as numbers or a Boolean value (a value type) uses an expected default for that value.

segment.source: For example, 0 for integers and floating-point numbers, false for a Boolean.
segment.target: For example, 0 for integers and floating-point numbers, false for a Boolean.

segment.source: A property that uses a Windows Runtime structure has a default value that's obtained by calling that structure's implicit default constructor.
segment.target: A property that uses a Windows Runtime structure has a default value that's obtained by calling that structure's implicit default constructor.

segment.source: This constructor uses the defaults for each of the basic value fields of the structure.
segment.target: This constructor uses the defaults for each of the basic value fields of the structure.

segment.source: For example, a default for a Point value is initialized with its X and Y values as 0.
segment.target: For example, a default for a Point value is initialized with its X and Y values as 0.

segment.source: A property that uses an enumeration has a default value of the first defined member in that enumeration.
segment.target: A property that uses an enumeration has a default value of the first defined member in that enumeration.

segment.source: Check the reference for specific enumerations to see what the default value is.
segment.target: Check the reference for specific enumerations to see what the default value is.

segment.source: A property that uses a string (System.String for .NET, Platform::String for C++/CX) has a default value of an empty string ("").
segment.target: A property that uses a string (System.String for .NET, Platform::String for C++/CX) has a default value of an empty string ("").

segment.source: Collection properties aren't typically implemented as dependency properties, for reasons discussed further on in this topic.
segment.target: Collection properties aren't typically implemented as dependency properties, for reasons discussed further on in this topic.

segment.source: But if you implement a custom collection property and you want it to be a dependency property, make sure to avoid an unintentional singleton as described near the end of Custom dependency properties.
segment.target: But if you implement a custom collection property and you want it to be a dependency property, make sure to avoid an unintentional singleton as described near the end of Custom dependency properties.

segment.source: Property functionality provided by a dependency property
segment.target: Property functionality provided by a dependency property

segment.source: Data binding
segment.target: Data binding

segment.source: A dependency property can have its value set through applying a data binding.
segment.target: A dependency property can have its value set through applying a data binding.

segment.source: Data binding uses the {Binding} markup extension syntax in XAML, or the Binding class in code.
segment.target: Data binding uses the {Binding} markup extension syntax in XAML, or the Binding class in code.

segment.source: For a databound property, the final property value determination is deferred until run time.
segment.target: For a databound property, the final property value determination is deferred until run time.

segment.source: At that time the value is obtained from a data source.
segment.target: At that time the value is obtained from a data source.

segment.source: The role that the dependency property system plays here is enabling a placeholder behavior for operations like loading XAML when the value is not yet known, and then supplying the value at run time by interacting with the Windows Runtime data binding engine.
segment.target: The role that the dependency property system plays here is enabling a placeholder behavior for operations like loading XAML when the value is not yet known, and then supplying the value at run time by interacting with the Windows Runtime data binding engine.

segment.source: The following example sets the Text value for a TextBlock element, using a binding in XAML.
segment.target: The following example sets the Text value for a TextBlock element, using a binding in XAML.

segment.source: The binding uses an inherited data context and an object data source.
segment.target: The binding uses an inherited data context and an object data source.

segment.source: (Neither of these is shown in the shortened example; for a more complete sample that shows context and source, see Data binding in depth.)
segment.target: (Neither of these is shown in the shortened example; for a more complete sample that shows context and source, see Data binding in depth.)

segment.source: You can also establish bindings using code rather than XAML.
segment.target: You can also establish bindings using code rather than XAML.

segment.source: See SetBinding.
segment.target: See SetBinding.

segment.source: Note Bindings like this are treated as a local value for purposes of dependency property value precedence.
segment.target: Note Bindings like this are treated as a local value for purposes of dependency property value precedence.

segment.source: If you set another local value for a property that originally held a Binding value, you will overwrite the binding entirely, not just the binding's run-time value.
segment.target: If you set another local value for a property that originally held a Binding value, you will overwrite the binding entirely, not just the binding's run-time value.

segment.source: Binding sources, binding targets, the role of FrameworkElement
segment.target: Binding sources, binding targets, the role of FrameworkElement

segment.source: To be the source of a binding, a property does not need to be a dependency property; you can generally use any property as a binding source, although this depends on your programming language and each has certain edge cases.
segment.target: To be the source of a binding, a property does not need to be a dependency property; you can generally use any property as a binding source, although this depends on your programming language and each has certain edge cases.

segment.source: However, to be the target of a binding, that property must be a dependency property.
segment.target: However, to be the target of a binding, that property must be a dependency property.

segment.source: If you are creating a binding in code, note that the SetBinding API is defined only for FrameworkElement.
segment.target: If you are creating a binding in code, note that the SetBinding API is defined only for FrameworkElement.

segment.source: However, you can create a binding definition using BindingOperations instead, and thus reference any DependencyObject property.
segment.target: However, you can create a binding definition using BindingOperations instead, and thus reference any DependencyObject property.

segment.source: For either code or XAML, remember that DataContext is a FrameworkElement property.
segment.target: For either code or XAML, remember that DataContext is a FrameworkElement property.

segment.source: By using a form of parent-child property inheritance (typically established in XAML markup), the binding system can resolve a DataContext that exists on a parent element.
segment.target: By using a form of parent-child property inheritance (typically established in XAML markup), the binding system can resolve a DataContext that exists on a parent element.

segment.source: This inheritance can evaluate even if the child object (which has the target property) is not a FrameworkElement and therefore does not hold its own DataContext value.
segment.target: This inheritance can evaluate even if the child object (which has the target property) is not a FrameworkElement and therefore does not hold its own DataContext value.

segment.source: However, the parent element being inherited must be a FrameworkElement in order to set and hold the DataContext.
segment.target: However, the parent element being inherited must be a FrameworkElement in order to set and hold the DataContext.

segment.source: Alternatively, you must define the binding such that it can function with a null value for DataContext.
segment.target: Alternatively, you must define the binding such that it can function with a null value for DataContext.

segment.source: Wiring the binding is not the only thing that's needed for most data binding scenarios.
segment.target: Wiring the binding is not the only thing that's needed for most data binding scenarios.

segment.source: For a one-way or two-way binding to be effective, the source property must support change notifications that propagate to the binding system and thus the target.
segment.target: For a one-way or two-way binding to be effective, the source property must support change notifications that propagate to the binding system and thus the target.

segment.source: For custom binding sources, this means that the property must support INotifyPropertyChanged.
segment.target: For custom binding sources, this means that the property must support INotifyPropertyChanged.

segment.source: Collections should support INotifyCollectionChanged.
segment.target: Collections should support INotifyCollectionChanged.

segment.source: Certain classes support these interfaces in their implementations so that they are useful as base classes for data binding scenarios; an example of such a class is ObservableCollectionT.
segment.target: Certain classes support these interfaces in their implementations so that they are useful as base classes for data binding scenarios; an example of such a class is ObservableCollectionT.

segment.source: For more information on data binding and how data binding relates to the property system, see Data binding in depth.
segment.target: For more information on data binding and how data binding relates to the property system, see Data binding in depth.

segment.source: Note The types listed here support Microsoft .NET data sources.
segment.target: Note The types listed here support Microsoft .NET data sources.

segment.source: C++/CX data sources use different interfaces for change notification or observable behavior, see Data binding in depth.
segment.target: C++/CX data sources use different interfaces for change notification or observable behavior, see Data binding in depth.

segment.source: Styles and templates
segment.target: Styles and templates

segment.source: Styles and templates are two of the scenarios for properties being defined as dependency properties.
segment.target: Styles and templates are two of the scenarios for properties being defined as dependency properties.

segment.source: Styles are useful for setting properties that define the app's UI.
segment.target: Styles are useful for setting properties that define the app's UI.

segment.source: Styles are defined as resources in XAML, either as an entry in a Resources collection, or in separate XAML files such as theme resource dictionaries.
segment.target: Styles are defined as resources in XAML, either as an entry in a Resources collection, or in separate XAML files such as theme resource dictionaries.

segment.source: Styles interact with the property system because they contain setters for properties.
segment.target: Styles interact with the property system because they contain setters for properties.

segment.source: The most important property here is the Control.Template property of a Control: it defines most of the visual appearance and visual state for a Control.
segment.target: The most important property here is the Control.Template property of a Control: it defines most of the visual appearance and visual state for a Control.

segment.source: For more info on styles, and some example XAML that defines a Style and uses setters, see Styling controls.
segment.target: For more info on styles, and some example XAML that defines a Style and uses setters, see Styling controls.

segment.source: Values that come from styles or templates are deferred values, similar to bindings.
segment.target: Values that come from styles or templates are deferred values, similar to bindings.

segment.source: This is so that control users can re-template controls or redefine styles.
segment.target: This is so that control users can re-template controls or redefine styles.

segment.source: And that's why property setters in styles can only act on dependency properties, not ordinary properties.
segment.target: And that's why property setters in styles can only act on dependency properties, not ordinary properties.

segment.source: Storyboarded animations
segment.target: Storyboarded animations

segment.source: You can animate a dependency property's value using a storyboarded animation.
segment.target: You can animate a dependency property's value using a storyboarded animation.

segment.source: Storyboarded animations in the Windows Runtime are not merely visual decorations.
segment.target: Storyboarded animations in the Windows Runtime are not merely visual decorations.

segment.source: It's more useful to think of animations as being a state machine technique that can set the values of individual properties or of all properties and visuals of a control, and change these values over time.
segment.target: It's more useful to think of animations as being a state machine technique that can set the values of individual properties or of all properties and visuals of a control, and change these values over time.

segment.source: To be animated, the animation's target property must be a dependency property.
segment.target: To be animated, the animation's target property must be a dependency property.

segment.source: Also, to be animated, the target property's value type must be supported by one of the existing Timeline-derived animation types.
segment.target: Also, to be animated, the target property's value type must be supported by one of the existing Timeline-derived animation types.

segment.source: Values of Color, Double and Point can be animated using either interpolation or keyframe techniques.
segment.target: Values of Color, Double and Point can be animated using either interpolation or keyframe techniques.

segment.source: Most other values can be animated using discrete Object key frames.
segment.target: Most other values can be animated using discrete Object key frames.

segment.source: When an animation is applied and running, the animated value operates at a higher precedence than any value (such as a local value) that the property otherwise has.
segment.target: When an animation is applied and running, the animated value operates at a higher precedence than any value (such as a local value) that the property otherwise has.

segment.source: Animations also have an optional HoldEnd behavior that can cause animations to apply to property values even if the animation visually appears to be stopped.
segment.target: Animations also have an optional HoldEnd behavior that can cause animations to apply to property values even if the animation visually appears to be stopped.

segment.source: The state machine principle is embodied by the use of storyboarded animations as part of the VisualStateManager state model for controls.
segment.target: The state machine principle is embodied by the use of storyboarded animations as part of the VisualStateManager state model for controls.

segment.source: For more info on storyboarded animations, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info on storyboarded animations, see Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: For more info on VisualStateManager and defining visual states for controls, see Storyboarded animations for visual states or Quickstart: Control templates.
segment.target: For more info on VisualStateManager and defining visual states for controls, see Storyboarded animations for visual states or Quickstart: Control templates.

segment.source: Property-changed behavior
segment.target: Property-changed behavior

segment.source: Property-changed behavior is the origin of the "dependency" part of dependency property terminology.
segment.target: Property-changed behavior is the origin of the "dependency" part of dependency property terminology.

segment.source: Maintaining valid values for a property when another property can influence the first property's value is a difficult development problem in many frameworks.
segment.target: Maintaining valid values for a property when another property can influence the first property's value is a difficult development problem in many frameworks.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime property system, each dependency property can specify a callback that is invoked whenever its property value changes.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime property system, each dependency property can specify a callback that is invoked whenever its property value changes.

segment.source: This callback can be used to notify or change related property values, in a generally synchronous manner.
segment.target: This callback can be used to notify or change related property values, in a generally synchronous manner.

segment.source: Many existing dependency properties have a property-changed behavior.
segment.target: Many existing dependency properties have a property-changed behavior.

segment.source: You can also add similar callback behavior to custom dependency properties, and implement your own property-changed callbacks.
segment.target: You can also add similar callback behavior to custom dependency properties, and implement your own property-changed callbacks.

segment.source: See Custom dependency properties for an example.
segment.target: See Custom dependency properties for an example.

segment.source: Default value and ClearValue
segment.target: Default value and ClearValue

segment.source: A dependency property can have a default value defined as part of its property metadata.
segment.target: A dependency property can have a default value defined as part of its property metadata.

segment.source: For a dependency property, its default value doesn't become irrelevant after the property's been set the first time.
segment.target: For a dependency property, its default value doesn't become irrelevant after the property's been set the first time.

segment.source: The default value might apply again at run-time whenever some other determinant in value precedence disappears.
segment.target: The default value might apply again at run-time whenever some other determinant in value precedence disappears.

segment.source: (Dependency property value precedence is discussed in the next section.) For example, you might deliberately remove a style value or an animation that applies to a property, but you want the value to be a reasonable default after you do so.
segment.target: (Dependency property value precedence is discussed in the next section.) For example, you might deliberately remove a style value or an animation that applies to a property, but you want the value to be a reasonable default after you do so.

segment.source: The dependency property default value can provide this value, without needing to specifically set each property's value as an extra step.
segment.target: The dependency property default value can provide this value, without needing to specifically set each property's value as an extra step.

segment.source: You can deliberately set a property to the default value even after you have already set it with a local value.
segment.target: You can deliberately set a property to the default value even after you have already set it with a local value.

segment.source: To reset a value to be the default again, and also to enable other participants in precedence that might override the default but not a local value, call the ClearValue method (reference the property to clear as a method parameter).
segment.target: To reset a value to be the default again, and also to enable other participants in precedence that might override the default but not a local value, call the ClearValue method (reference the property to clear as a method parameter).

segment.source: You don't always want the property to literally use the default value, but clearing the local value and reverting to the default value might enable another item in precedence that you want to act now, such as using the value that came from a style setter in a control template.
segment.target: You don't always want the property to literally use the default value, but clearing the local value and reverting to the default value might enable another item in precedence that you want to act now, such as using the value that came from a style setter in a control template.

segment.source: DependencyObject and threading
segment.target: DependencyObject and threading

segment.source: All DependencyObject instances must be created on the UI thread which is associated with the current Window that is shown by a Windows Runtime app.
segment.target: All DependencyObject instances must be created on the UI thread which is associated with the current Window that is shown by a Windows Runtime app.

segment.source: Although each DependencyObject must be created on the main UI thread, the objects can be accessed using a dispatcher reference from other threads, by accessing the Dispatcher property.
segment.target: Although each DependencyObject must be created on the main UI thread, the objects can be accessed using a dispatcher reference from other threads, by accessing the Dispatcher property.

segment.source: Then you can call methods such as RunAsync on the CoreDispatcher object, and execute your code within the rules of thread restrictions on the UI thread.
segment.target: Then you can call methods such as RunAsync on the CoreDispatcher object, and execute your code within the rules of thread restrictions on the UI thread.

segment.source: The threading aspects of DependencyObject are relevant because it generally means that only code that runs on the UI thread can change or even read the value of a dependency property.
segment.target: The threading aspects of DependencyObject are relevant because it generally means that only code that runs on the UI thread can change or even read the value of a dependency property.

segment.source: Threading issues can usually be avoided in typical UI code that makes correct use of async patterns and background worker threads.
segment.target: Threading issues can usually be avoided in typical UI code that makes correct use of async patterns and background worker threads.

segment.source: You typically only run into DependencyObject-related threading issues if you are defining your own DependencyObject types and you attempt to use them for data sources or other scenarios where a DependencyObject isn't necessarily appropriate.
segment.target: You typically only run into DependencyObject-related threading issues if you are defining your own DependencyObject types and you attempt to use them for data sources or other scenarios where a DependencyObject isn't necessarily appropriate.
